docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate health care debate has just begun, and already there is evidence that it is going to be a slog. For much of Tuesday, Senate Democrats had predicted that there would be an early evening vote on the first amendment to the legislation, a proposal by Senator Barbara A. Mikulski, Democrat of Maryland, to require insurers to provide a package of enhanced health benefits to women with no co-payments.
docs.abstract: Early going indicates that Senate health care debate, just getting underway, is going to take time, with possibility of filibusters (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A federal panel said Tuesday that regional differences in the use of health care services were substantial but smaller than many experts have suggested. The panel, the Medicare Payment Advisory Commission, found that the use of services by Medicare beneficiaries in the Miami area was almost 40 percent higher than the national average and 10 percent higher than the average for any other large metropolitan area.
docs.abstract: Medicare Payment Advisory Commission finds that regional differences in use of health care services are substantial but smaller than may experts suggest (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: As things look now, the Senate apparently will not vote Tuesday on a proposed package of comprehensive health benefits for women, according to aides to Senator Barbara Mikulski, Democrat of Maryland and the lead sponsor of the proposal.

headline.main: Tuesday Vote on Mikulski Amendment Now Doubtful

docs.abstract: A Senate vote on Milkulski amendment to health bill now looks doubtful.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a pitch to two of America's most potent political constituencies, Senate Democrats and Republicans turned the first full day of debate over major health care legislation into a battle over who would better protect the vulnerable.

docs.lead_paragraph: Some liberal Democrats are still insisting that the "public option" is a make-or-break issue for the health care legislation. And that includes some without a vote in Congress, like Howard Dean.

headline.main: Tea With Mr. Dean and the Public Option

docs.abstract: Invited for tea at Yale, Howard Dean (class of '71) lobbies for the public option.
